results.title: With Finnish Arrests, Atrocity in Iraq Has Distant Fallout
results.abstract: Two refugees have been held in connection with an ISIS massacre near Tikrit, based on a video, but even with such evidence, it’s a challenge to hold suspects accountable for atrocities.
des_facet: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis
War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: A suspect, center, at a courthouse in Tampere, Finland, this month. He is believed to be one of the Iraqi twin brothers implicated in a massacre near Tikrit, Iraq, in June 2014.
multimedia.copyright: Anni Reenpaa/Lehtikuva, via Associated Press

results.title: Rebuke of Insurgent Reveals Fractures in Taliban’s Leadership
results.abstract: A letter by the religious leaders criticized the new insurgent leader for the violent discipline of his commanders, reflecting deep tensions in the hierarchy.
results.byline: By MUJIB MASHAL and TAIMOOR SHAH

multimedia.caption: An Afghan police officer searching for drugs in Nimroz Province this spring. The top Taliban commander, Mullah Akhtar Mansour, has a tight grip on trafficking of opium by the Taliban.

results.title: Experts and Officials Diverge on ISIS as a Hacking Threat
results.abstract: Officials wonder aloud if public infrastructure could be digitally disabled, but researchers say ISIS is not nearly so sophisticated, or inclined.
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: George Osborne, Britain's chancellor of the Exchequer, says ISIS is trying to develop the ability to digitally disable public infrastructure. Others are less convinced.
multimedia.copyright: Pool photo by Andy Rain

results.title: New York Builders Pay Huge Buyouts to Tenants in the Way
results.abstract: Multimillion-dollar payouts are becoming more common for residents in rent-regulated apartments in exceptionally lucrative New York real estate.

results.title: Searching for Redemption in Vietnam
results.abstract: Six Americans who lost their fathers in the war met in Ho Chi Minh City with Vietnamese who also lost their parents and found a shared sadness, but no anger.

results.title: Personal Journeys: How I Escaped Vietnam
results.abstract: A family vacation revives thoughts about fleeing South Vietnam as a child.

multimedia.caption: TAN PHU, 1969, When I was about 5, my sister and I rode a bike to flee a bombing. The dirt road, left, trembled from the explosions and bright fireballs flashed in the distance. Our dog trotted close behind. The bombing continued through the night.
multimedia.copyright: Minh Uong/The New York Times

results.title: December Heat Tricks Spring Flowers Into Bloom
results.abstract: Warm soil and air temperatures are throwing off several varieties, as this autumn was the warmest on record in the contiguous United States.

multimedia.caption: A Viburnum x bodnantense "Dawn" flower at the New York Botanical Garden. An official at the garden said the blooming in December was unusual.

results.title: Unseasonable Greetings in City Searching for Jack Frost
results.abstract: The city has been so warm that the average temperature for the month could be 14 degrees above normal, the largest such deviation on record, and the high for Dec. 24 is forecast to be 73.

results.title: School Expresses ‘Sorrow and Shame’ Over Sexual Abuse
results.abstract: An inquiry by St. George’s School in Rhode Island found that 26 students were abused by employees in the 1970s and ’80s.

multimedia.caption: St. George's School in Middletown, R.I. The school on Wednesday released to alumni a report on its investigation of sexual abuse by employees in the 1970s and '80s.

results.title: The Horace Mann School’s History of Abuse (June 6, 2012)
results.abstract: Many years later, graduates of the Horace Mann School, an elite private school in New York, are finally able to tell their stories of sexual abuse.

results.title: Rubio Looks in Mirror and Sees Republican Obama
results.abstract: Marco Rubio suggested that Republicans should look at the president’s liberal accomplishments and hope for similar victories of the conservative kind with him in office.

results.title: Tornado Leaves Long Path of Destruction in South
results.abstract: A tornado appeared to have raced for more than 130 miles across Mississippi and Tennessee on Wednesday, part of a weather system that killed at least 10 people.
results.byline: By LACEY RUSSELL, ALAN BLINDER and CYNTHIA HOWLE

results.title: Wealthy Men Are Targeted in Nightclubs, Police Say
results.abstract: In several incidents this year, men have reported taking women home from restaurants and nightclubs only to find luxury goods have been stolen.

results.title: In Video, Israeli Extremists Celebrate Child’s Death
results.abstract: Officials said they were investigating the video, taken at a wedding. Guests there appeared to be cheering the death of 18-month-old Ali Dawabsheh.

results.title: Last Stand in Oakland? Raiders Fans Pray Not
results.abstract: The Raiders’ game Thursday night against the San Diego Chargers could be their last home game ever in Oakland, as the team is expected to apply to relocate to Los Angeles.

multimedia.caption: Raiders fans at O.co Coliseum on Thursday. The Raiders, the Chargers and the Rams are expected to apply to relocate to Los Angeles.

results.title: Best of 2015: How One Stupid Tweet Blew Up Justine Sacco’s Life
results.abstract: The Times is highlighting some of its most engaging journalism of the year, including a piece on the unique 21st-century misery of the online shaming victim.
